name: Crown and Council
description: Crown and Council is a casual strategy game with short game sessions.

reviews.review_text: Great game for being 100% free

This is a very simple and fun strategy game. Others have mentioned that the interface is a little irritating at times with clicks on countries not always registering. Honestly, not that big of a deal but I can see how it may frustrate some people. My biggest problem with this game is the AI is not that intelligent. Once you understand how the game works it becomes mindlessly easy. The AI tends to spend a lot of money on buildings while you are sweeping up huge swaths of land, at which point you have large amounts of money coming in and you can quickly dominate the board. The AI also tends to focus on small border enemies and completely ignores you while you build a massive empire. There seems to be some kind of animosity mechanic in the game where if you don't attack another player, they will generally leave you alone until they have to attack you because you're the only one left, or there is no other way for them to expand. I have found that, generally, it is best to just ignore building anything and focus on grabbing as much land as possible. Then use your increased income to crush your enemies. Several people have said this game is like Risk. Anyone saying that has never played Risk before. This game has little in common with Risk.  Basically a fun little game to play around with but it gets old fairly fast.
Overall a fantastic game, it is very simplistic yet it's a very complex and enjoyable game. However, the game's resolution can get annoying and is something that needs to be fixed.

I am realyl enjoying playing Crown and Council, and would highly recommend it.   Pros:  - Simplistic, easy to pick up.  - Really fun, and addictive. Similiar turn-based strategy to the RISK board games, and Civilization V.  Cons:  - The game is confined to a square window that cannot be fullscreened or put into 16:9. (This will likely be changed, I can respect the square design as it seems to be stylistic, but I'd love fullscreen capabilities.)   I also created a YouTube video of me playing a round of Crown and Council:         YouTube™ Video:  How To Play Crown and Council (Mojang's Free To Play Steam Game)

A nice little game to play for a bit. It took >10 seconds to download, which is faster than some mods. I haven't noticed any issues with clicking as some others have.   PROS:  - Free - requires some strategy - AI seems reasonable - Apparently there's procedural terrain generation  CONS: - RNG. Capturing a territory is a random chance, so you can even fail to capture unguarded territory. There are also RNG plagues and rebellions. All together they make the game less strategic, so each should really be replaces with established mechanics (like maybe a defense bar for forts, or an unrest meter in territory).

I have only seen two bad reviews that were written by somebody that had more than two hours on the game, and neither of those people have as many hours as I do. I can safely say that this game is AWESOME.  ->Cons: -Relies on RNG -Pretty much Risk.  ->Pros: -Great for short, fast paced games. -Requires strategy and thinking ahead -Reguires smart use of money and land placement

It's free.   That being said the RNG is SO strong in this game. After the first few missions (when it hits 4 players) it seems that RNG can ruin a game. Attack the same place multiple times and don't even get a hit (I'm assuming there are misses) but then the AI comes in and takes down a fresh fort in 1 hit.   If I'm going to have a chance at failing an attack, maybe let me know why it failed?  Unable to resize the window and also has problems with losing your current action selection? Would not be as unbearable to deal with if there were hotkeys for the actions.  Assuming the QOL is improved and maybe a little less RNG and this would be a GREAT game to play in your freetime.

The RNG is so terribly bad and no feedback given which equals constant frustration about trying to take over territories. The first 2 maps were a breeze, with proper mapping and some planning it's simple enough to progress; however, after literally taking 3 turns building up enough gold to attack a single territory 8 times with no success, only to have the AI immediately take over 2 of my fortified territories with 2 attacks was my limit.  The RNG on this game is WAY too erratic, and doesn't actually make the game pleasant to play.

The idea behind the game is fascinating.  However, there are bugs that making this simple clicker not playable. 1. The controls are sometimes unresponsive. 2. The resolution is unchangable and if your using a screen resolution of 1366x786 or less, you won't see the whole game-window 3. The game sometimes won't let you click anything, only allowing you to end your turn (the only thing you do by anything other than pointing and clicking).

It's free so there is no reason not to give it a try, but don't expect too much.  The game has one play mode in which the rich inevitably get richer and there is no catchup mechanic (unless you count pure RNG). If you get a few bad results at the beginning of the game, you lose. There are a variety of structures you can build, but I found I always did worse when I built them. The main winning strategy is just to charge right at the nearest opponent, kill them on turn 2 or 3, then charge at the next nearest. Only if I had extra gold would I build anything. This 'strategy' won me almost every game I played, often in less than a minute or two.  Add in the fact that there are no options at all and sometimes it takes several mouse clicks for the game to realize you did anything and you've got a very weak game.

I've been playing this for a few hours, since i picked it up last week. At first, it was pretty difficult to learn the ins-and-outs of how to play effectively, but i think i got the hang of it, after some trial-and-error. However, On Map 39, I seem unable to win, not for lack of trying mind you. The A.I. factions are simply immortal. Doesn't matter if i have castles on every province, Red and Yellow keep their minimum incomes and take back a few territories every turn. It's pretty frustrating, as you can imagine. I'm left wonderin if this is an isolated bug, or if other players are having the same issue. As it stands, I dont think I'll be playing this game anymore, not as long as the stage is unwinnable.

This should be a fun game. And for the first few minutes it is. But as soon as you play for more than half an hour or so, it becomes clear that this game needs some fundamental tweaking in order to not be mind-meltingly frustrating. I got stuck for over half an hour on one level because the RNG appears to be genuinely random, or favoring the enemy characters. As soon as I got a foothold, I immediately lost it, and was back to square one. Because the game is so simple, especially on that particular map, winning is almost completely random because there isn't any real way to play more skillfully than the computer. At least in the first couple levels, when there aren't that many different units to use, I figure the game needs to give the player an edge so they can actually win at some point and go on to something more complicated that is actually challenging instead of based completely on chance. If not for this aspect, I would totally reccomend this game.

This game while emulating elements of 'swarm' strategy games does not have the inherent mechanism in place that make the type enjoyable. To conquer adjacent provinces the player must simply click and 'hope' that the unseen and random mathematics in the background works. The only advantage having a multitude of provinces is you get more attempts at attacking, however unlike games such as Risk where you can stack your numbers advantage.   This game provides what appears to be a 50% win/loss ratio. Having a fortress built seems the only way to enhance your defence, but again the benefit/penalty is unseen and appears to be a 30% win/loss ratio (attacker).  This game is free and can be a time sink for 5-10mins. It lacks polish and consideration of tactical and strategic considerations.
